document_name: Enhanced Coordination to Drought in Kenya PID.pdf
http://www.undp.org/content/dam/undp/documents/projects/KEN/00057861/Enhanced Coordination to Drought in Kenya PID.pdf

outputs.output_descr: Kenya is vulnerable to disasters, especially triggered by natural hazards. Drought and floods have been pointed out as the most frequent hazards, but they are not the only ones. Fire, landslides, environmental degradation, HIV/AIDS, disease epidemics, conflict and more are also hazards in Kenya that bring disasters. Although a disaster risk management structure exists in Kenya, much of the current structure is ad hoc. National policies and plans are not in place and lack of resources remain a constant challenge. There is a strong need for an efficient and effective insitutional and legal framework for disaster risk management in the country.

Kenya risks losing gains made on key millennium development goals such as access to education and a reduction in child mortality due to severe drought conditions. The country is experiencing severe dry conditions, the effects of the La Nina predicted by IGAD climate prediction and application centre (ICPAC) in collaboration with the Kenya Meteorological Department. It is critical to enhance capcaity for bringing a well-coordinated response to drought in the country and the main focus will be to strengthen the technical and coordination capacities of Government and other key stake holders in Early Recovery.

project_descr: Disaster Risk Reduction effectiveness strengthened, enhanced and supported at all levels in Kenya.
